AP WORLD SYMPOSIUM '90s: Caribbean _ Trouble on the Horizon
With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: The Caribbean, which comprises some of the world's poorest and most heavily indebted nations, faces the prospect of increasing economic and social pressures in the 1990s. Problems confronting the two dozen island states south of Florida range from rising unemployment and shrinking markets for sugar and bananas to the spread of AIDS and drug trafficking. Some analysts believe the strain could be severe enough to produce a resurgence of radical politics and civil unrest. ``There is just no way for stable democracy to continue in these islands unless more jobs and income are generated,'' said John Collins, adviser on the Caribbean for Gov. Rafael Hernandez Colon of Puerto Rico. While celebrating the 500th anniversary of Colombus' discovery of the New World in 1992, the Caribbean will likely find itself still coping with the effects of events dictated far from its shores. Caribbean leaders have expressed concern, for example, that the Cold War thaw could divert Western investment from their region to the nations emerging from communist domination in Eastern Europe. Likewise, Cuba could be forced to reduce its economic dependence on the Soviet bloc, said Norman Girvan of Jamaica, president of the Association of Caribbean Economists. ``What's happening in Western Europe is changing our external environment,'' he said. ``What's happening in Eastern Europe must change the environment of Cuba.'' For much of the region, one of the darkest clouds on the horizon is the proposed single European market after 1992. A unified market would lift trade barriers within the 12-nation European Economic Community and harmonize foreign trade agreements. Among the nations most at risk are the Windward Islands of Dominica, St. Lucia, St. Vincent and Grenada, which together ship 240,000 tons of bananas a year to Britain. After 1992, they could lose preferential access to the British market and face fierce competition from more efficient banana producers elsewhere. Many also fear the loss of benefits as a result of the new U.S.-Canadian trade accord and proposed changes in the Caribbean Basin Initiative, the program set up by the Reagan administration to promote U.S.-oriented economic and political development in the Caribbean and Central America. ``The next decade is going to test the very theory that microstates can survive in a world increasingly dominated by massive trading blocs,'' said Larry Birns, director of the Washington-based Council on Hemispheric Affairs. Propects for the sugar industry, meanwhile, are dimmed by years of sharply declining U.S. import quotas, low world prices and increasing reliance on corn sweeteners and U.S. and European sugar beets. Compton Bourne, professor of economics at the University of the West Indies in Trinidad, said he thought pressure would build on Caribbean governments to follow through on commitments to integrate their economies and pool limited resources. But he said propects for the 1990s largely depended on the willingness of developed nations to reduce the region's debt burden and provide sorely needed investment. Analysts said the expected loss of revenue from traditional exports would probably accelerate a move into tourism, already the No. 1 earner of foreign exchange for several islands, and enhance such industries as computer data entry that use cheap, semi-skilled labor. Birns said there was a danger that environmental considerations will be overwhelmed by the rush to exploit the islands' lucrative tourism potential. Tourism is also regarded as a significant factor in the rapid spread of AIDS, prostitution and drug use throughout the Caribbean. Although conservative, pro-U.S. governments dominate the region, Birns said, ``the approaching crisis'' could give rise to radically leftist leadership and possible destabilization. If Western lending institutions such as the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank force further economic austerity on such debt-ridden nations as Guyana, Jamaica and Trinidad, ``you're going to see an increasingly dangerous situation,'' Birns said. He added that the Caribbean of the 1990s would figure more prominently in U.S. policy because of increased immigration and closer scrutiny of the region's role as a major drug-trafficking route and source of money-laundering through offshore banks. Haiti, the Caribbean's perennial trouble spot, approaches the new decade at a political crossroads. Opinion is divided over whether Haiti's military leader, Lt. Gen. Prosper Avril, will fulfill his pledge to turn over power to a civilian government in elections scheduled for the fall of 1990. No one expects a swift solution to the country's profound economic problems.
